The Project will form part of the ongoing flagship poverty reduction 
program  of  the  Government  of  Indonesia—the  National  Program 
for  Community  Empowerment  (PNPM  Mandiri).  It  will  rehabilitate 
and expand rural infrastructure in about 1,650 poor and/or isolated 
villages in Jambi, Lampung, Riau, and South Sumatra provinces. 
The  Project  will  follow  a  community-driven  development  (CDD) 
approach and will benefit about 2 million people, or about 400,000 
households. 
 
Poverty in Indonesia is overwhelmingly a rural problem with about 
two thirds of the country’s poor living in rural areas. The causes of 
rural  poverty  include  lack  of  access  to  health,  education,  safe 
water,  and  sanitation  services;  and  an  absence  of  economic 
opportunities  compounded  by  poor  rural  connectivity,  which  is  a 
lack of infrastructure in isolated areas with difficult geography and 
inadequate  links  to  markets.  Nearly  one  of  five  rural  villages  is 
inaccessible  part  of  the  year,  even  by  four-wheel-drive  vehicles. 
Poor  and  disadvantaged  rural  people  are  vulnerable  to  external 
shocks  and  could  fall  back  into  poverty  in  the  event  of  sickness, 
natural disaster, harvest failure, or rising food prices.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Before  the  Asian  financial  crisis  that  began  in  1997,  Indonesia  had  been  successful  in 
fighting  poverty.  The  incidence  of  poverty  dropped  from  more  than  50%  in  1970  to  less  than 
18%  in  1996.  However,  the  financial  crisis  unraveled  years  of  progress  attained  toward 
sustainable poverty reduction and plunged more than a quarter of Indonesia’s population below 
the  poverty  line.  After  the  crisis,  the  Government  scaled  up  its  efforts  to  fight  poverty,  which 
included  implementation  of  numerous  community-driven  development  (CDD)  projects.  These 
efforts  have  reduced  the  number  of  people  living  in  poverty  to  pre-crisis  levels.  In  2008,  the 
number  of  poor  was  35.0  million,  corresponding  to  a  poverty  incidence  of  15.4%.  However, 
Indonesia still faces a serious challenge in reaching the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) of 
a poverty incidence of 7.6% in 2015.1 In addition, the country has a large number of vulnerable 
near poor, with almost 50% of the population still living on less than $2 a day.  
 
3.  
Poverty in Indonesia is overwhelmingly a rural problem with more than two thirds of the 
country’s poor living in rural areas. The causes of rural poverty include lack of access to health, 
education,  safe  water,  and  sanitation  services;  and  an  absence  of  economic  opportunities, 
compounded  by  poor  rural  connectivity,  which  is  a  lack  of  infrastructure  in  isolated  areas  with 
difficult  geography  and  inadequate  links  to  markets.  Nearly  one  of  five  rural  villages  is 
inaccessible  for  part  of  the  year,  even  by  four-wheel-drive  vehicles.  The  rural  population  is 
vulnerable to external shocks and could fall back into poverty in the event of sickness, natural 
disaster, harvest failure, or rising food prices. They also have extremely limited access to basic 
services  (e.g.,  health  and  education),  capital,  and  infrastructure.  The  incidence  of  poverty 
continues to be much higher in rural areas (18.9%) than in urban areas (11.7%).2 
 
4.  
The Government of Indonesia has made poverty reduction a priority in its medium-term 
and annual plans. The Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJM) 2004–2009 provides strategic 
direction for the Government in addressing poverty, incorporating key elements of the National 
Poverty Reduction Strategy (SNPK) and highlighting the importance of achieving the MDGs. In 
response  to  rising  poverty  levels,  the  Government  issued  a  poverty  reduction  action  plan—in 
line  with  the  SNPK—with  the  theme  of  increasing  employment  opportunities  and  accelerating 
poverty reduction. A study by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) confirmed that in addition to 
the  income-related  impacts,  investments  in  infrastructure  also  generate  non-income  impacts 
such as improvements in health, education, security, and participation.3 Taking into account the 
important  role  of  infrastructure  development  in  reducing  poverty,  the  RPJM  emphasizes  the 
need for increased investments in infrastructure in general and rural infrastructure in particular. 
 
5.  
Following the elections in late 2004, the Government adopted a policy reorienting public 
sector expenditures from general consumptive subsidies to targeted interventions aimed at the

In  April  2007,  the  Government  launched  the  National  Program  for  Community 
Empowerment  (PNPM  Mandiri),  which  will  cover  all  villages  in  the  country  during  2008–2015. 
This  much  larger  program  will  aim  to  reduce  by  promoting  community  participation  in 
development planning and management, and delivery of basic services, including infrastructure. 
It is intended to help the country achieve MDG targets by 2015. The budgets for 2008 and 2009

simple  and  transparent  funds  flow  mechanisms,  and  emphasizes  operation  and  maintenance 
(O&M)  of  completed  works.  An  overview  of  the  PNPM  Mandiri  is  in  Appendix  2,  and 
Supplementary Appendix A provides details of the program.

Adequacy and Sustainability of Rural Infrastructure 

8. 
For many years before the Asian financial crisis erupted in 1997, Indonesia successfully 
used  infrastructure  investments  to  support  poverty  reduction  and  economic  development. 
However, the financial shock resulted in cancellation or suspension of many planned public and 
private infrastructure projects. Subsequent governments during 1998–2004 were burdened with 
the  more  urgent  tasks  of  financial  sector  restructuring  and  fiscal  consolidation.  As  a  result, 
infrastructure investments, which accounted for more than 6% of gross domestic product before 
1997, fell to a low of 2% in 2000 and have only reached just over 3% in recent years, reflecting 
a  sharp  decline  in  public  and  private  spending.  Since  1997,  only  basic  preservation  and 
maintenance  of  infrastructure  have  taken  place,  but  very  little  expansion.  A  more  detailed 
analysis of the infrastructure gap is in Appendix 3.

Challenges in Public Service Delivery 

11. 
Traditionally, much of the development spending by local governments in Indonesia has 
been  centrally  sponsored,  financed,  and  implemented.  ADB  and  other  development  partners 
have  largely  supported  local  development  initiatives  through  the  Government.  While  the 
transaction costs of ensuring sound public investment and project management are always high 
in  a  large  and  diverse  country  like  Indonesia,  the  devolution  of  authority  to  local  governments 
has  brought  about  three  additional  challenges.  First,  the  appropriate  level  of  devolution  of 
financing  must  be  determined.  Second,  the  capacity  of  local  governments  as  new  entities  to 
effectively  plan  and  execute  public  investment  projects  is  limited.  Third,  ensuring  adequate 
fiduciary governance in the management of investment projects is complex.

Community Ownership 

38. 
The  Project’s  CDD  approach  will  help  develop  a  sense  of  ownership  among  the 
community  members.  The  RISP  and  other  past  CDD  projects,  both  within  and  outside  of

Benefits and Impacts 

A. 
 
64. 
Investment  in  priority  rural  infrastructure  will  directly  benefit  about  2  million  people,  or 
400,000  households,  in  1,650  villages  in  the  project  area.  Anticipated  benefits  include  (i)

(iii) additional community and local government capacities. 
 

1. 

Economic and Financial Benefits 

Given  the  Project’s  CDD  approach,  the  communities  will  prioritize  their  infrastructure 
65. 
needs during implementation. Therefore, it is not possible to estimate an economic internal rate 
of return (EIRR) for the Project at this stage. However, many previous CDD projects that carried 
out community-level interventions in Indonesia have demonstrated high EIRRs for various types 
of  rural  infrastructure  facilities.  Appendix  14  summarizes  the  findings  of  evaluations  of  two 
recent projects with similar approaches and grant sizes. The experience of the RISP and World 
Bank-financed KDPs suggests an average EIRR of more than 50%. Given the large sunk costs 
that  the  Government  has  incurred  in  designing  and  implementing  the  PNPM  Mandiri,  the 
Project’s economic and financial benefits are anticipated to be larger than if the Project were a 
stand-alone  intervention.  The  Project  is  also  expected  to  generate  about  160,000  person-
months of employment. Overall, the PNPM Mandiri is expected to generate employment for 27 
million people.18 
 

2. 

Social and Poverty Reduction Benefits 

66.  
The  Project  will  target  poor  and  isolated  villages  in  less-developed  districts  that  lack 
basic  infrastructure.  As  such,  the  selected  villages  are  expected  to  have  higher-than-average 
poverty levels and be below the national achievement levels for MDGs for eradicating poverty 
and  hunger,  and  improving  access  to  water  and  sanitation.  The  water  supply  and  sanitation 
interventions  are  expected  to  reduce  time  and  costs  spent  on  obtaining  good-quality  water, 
while  diminishing  the  incidence  and  severity  of  waterborne  diseases.  Improvements  in  rural 
roads are expected to increase the availability and accessibility of education and health services 
to  the  rural  poor  and  near  poor.  A  healthier  population  with  easier  access  to  services  and 
markets,  and  with  more  time  to  engage  in  economic  activities,  will  have  the  opportunity  to 
improve its incomes and welfare.

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
Community-driven development (CDD) was introduced in Indonesia in 1998 in the midst 
1. 
of  two  major  events  that  had  devastating  effect  on  Indonesia’s  poor:  the  Asian  financial  crisis 
and  the  rapid  transition  to  decentralized  administration,  which  led  to  a  breakdown  in  service 
delivery mechanisms that had previously been managed directly by the central government. To 
address  inefficiencies  in  public  service  delivery,  in  1998  the  World  Bank  introduced  the 
Kecamatan (subdistrict) Development Program (KDP), which was followed by a number of CDD 
projects  by  various  development  partners.  Almost  half  of  ADB  project  loans  to  Indonesia 
approved since 1999 have CDD components. Supplementary Appendix F provides a review of 
all major CDD programs. 
 
2. 
The  extensive  experience  of  CDD  in  Indonesia  has  confirmed  the  success  of  this 
approach. Various studies show that CDD projects result in (i) better poverty targeting, ensuring 
that benefits accrue to poor; (ii) lower-cost and good-quality infrastructure due to transparency 
measures  in  decision  making  and  resource  allocation,  and  the  use  of  participatory  processes 
that  reduced  corruption;  (iii)  high  economic  returns;  (iv)  high  inclusion  of  vulnerable  and 
marginalized groups; and (v) quick disbursement of funds. 
 
3. 
Encouraged by the success of CDD programs, the Government adopted this approach—
with  a  defined  institutional  arrangement—as  a  key  strategy  for  its  poverty  reduction  and  rural 
development  initiatives  throughout  the  country.  The  Policy  on  Accelerating  Poverty  Reduction 
and Jobs Creation is linked to the achievement of targets set out in the country’s 2004—2009 
Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJM) and the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), and 
is  supported  by  two  programs:  the  National  Program  for  Community  Empowerment  (PNPM 
Mandiri) and the Conditional Cash Transfer Program. The PNPM Mandiri was officially launched 
on 30 April 2007 by the President of Indonesia. 
 
B.  
 
The  PNPM  Mandiri  is  a  nationwide  program  for  community  empowerment  aimed  at 
4. 
accelerating  poverty  reduction.  The  goal  of  the  program  is  to  empower  rural  and  urban 
communities to participate in development. The PNPM Mandiri promotes a spirit of cooperation 
and self-help within participating communities.  
 
5. 
The  program  was  initially  a  collection  of  community-based  poverty  reduction  programs 
implemented  by  different  ministries  and  supported  by  different  development  agencies  and  the 
Government.  The  PNPM  Mandiri  consolidates  the  different  community-based  programs  of 
different ministries and institutionalizes the experience of Indonesia in bottom-up planning and 
decision  making.  Different  programs  and  projects  were  reviewed  and  assessed,  and  the 
learning distilled, to form a single model for a community-based poverty reduction strategy. The 
PNPM  Mandiri  provides  a  single  framework  for  all  CDD  programs  in  Indonesia  and  will 
consolidate  scattered  and  sometimes  overlapping  programs  implemented  by  different  sectoral 
agencies.

Indonesia has managed to reduce the percentage of people living on less than $1/day to 
the  pre-crisis  level  of  less  than  18%.  However,  the  country  has  a  large  number  of  vulnerable 
near poor, with almost half of the population living on less than $2/day. About two thirds of the 
population lives in rural areas, and rural poverty exceeds urban poverty. There is a continuing 
disparity between urban and rural regions; the poverty rate is 18.9% in rural areas versus 11.7% 
in  urban  areas.  The  urban-rural  poverty  gap  remained  constant  between  2006  and  2007,  with 
poverty  falling  by  roughly  1.1  percentage  points  in  each  area.  From  the  1970s  to  the  1990s, 
there was little difference between poverty rates in the urban and rural areas, as the gap never 
exceeded  2.5  percentage  points  in  either  direction.  Since  1999  when  the  gap  widened,  rural 
poverty  has  been  consistently  8  percentage  points  above  the  urban  level.  There  is  a  strong 
linkage  between  poverty  and  lack  of  access  to  infrastructure.  Improved  local  community 
infrastructure can result in better health and education, safer water supply and sanitation, and 
better access to economic opportunities. All of these are basic rights stated in the Government's 
National Strategy for Poverty Reduction and incorporated into the Medium-Term Development 
Plan 2004–2009. The provision of infrastructure for poor communities will also help achieve the 
Millennium Development Goals.   
 
The  availability  of  infrastructure  services  in  rural  areas,  particularly  outside  Java  and 
4. 
Bali, is significantly below the national average. About 54% of rural villages are not connected 
through asphalt roads, and about one third of these lack year-round access, even by four-wheel 
drive  vehicles.  High  transportation  costs  in  these  communities  are  a  major  cause  of  poverty. 
Only  15%  of  rural  households  have  access  to  drinking  water  from  piped  or  pumped  sources, 
and just 21% have septic tanks for disposal of human waste. The low levels of access to safe 
drinking water and lack of adequate sanitation facilities contribute to the high incidence of such 
water-borne diseases as diarrhea, intestinal worms, and skin diseases. The incidence is higher 
among children and the elderly, and diarrhea is the second-largest cause of death and stunted 
growth among young children. Indonesia’s infant mortality rate is the highest among Southeast

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

 

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Prior to the Asian financial crisis, Indonesia had been successful in fighting poverty. The poverty rate, in terms of the 
population  living  below  $1/day,  decreased  from  more  than  50%  in  1970  to  less  than  20%  in  1997.  Although  the 
poverty  headcount  has  been  steadily  falling  since  1997,  poverty  remains  persistent  in  Indonesia.  Recent  surveys 
suggest  that  about  half  of  the  population  still  lived  below  the  $2/day  international  poverty  line  in  2007.  Continued 
economic growth rates contributed to lift living standards; however, the benefits of economic growth are not equally 
distributed  among  the  population.  Rural  poverty  is  significantly  higher  that  urban  poverty,  with  about  60%  of  the 
country’s poor living in rural areas. The causes of rural poverty include lack of access to key social services, absence 
of economic opportunities particularly in rural areas, poor infrastructure in villages, and inadequate market linkages.  
 
To address the issue of underdeveloped infrastructure hampering economic growth opportunities in poor rural areas, 
the Government of Indonesia’s (Government) National Strategy for Poverty Reduction (SNPK) identified increasing 
rural infrastructure investments as a key strategy to reduce poverty and regional disparities. According to the SNPK, 
infrastructure investments  will contribute to achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), as the impact of 
improved infrastructure will enhance poor people’s access to social services and markets, and generate income and 
employment opportunities. In line with the SNPK, the Government’s Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJM) 2004–
2009 further underlines the need for increased investments in infrastructure in general, and in rural infrastructure in 
particular, as an important vehicle for reducing poverty. 
 
In April 2007, the Government launched the National Program for Community Empowerment (PNPM Mandiri). The 
PNPM  Mandiri  builds  upon  Indonesia’s  accumulated  experience  with  community-driven  development  (CDD) 
programs  and  focuses  on  improving  local  governance  and  service  delivery  at  the  subdistrict  and  village  level  by 
encouraging  participatory  planning  and  providing  block  grants  for  rural  roads,  improving  water  and  sanitation 
facilities, and developing education and health services. The program will cover all villages in the country during the 
period 2008–2015. The PNPM Mandiri budget for 2008 and 2009 is about $1.4 billion and $2.0 billion, respectively. 
The  PNPM  Mandiri  promotes  inclusive  community  facilitation  in  planning  and  implementation  of  infrastructure 
improvements,  utilizes  simple  and  transparent  funds  flow  mechanisms,  and  puts  emphasis  on  operation  and 
maintenance  of  completed  works.  The  Project  is  built  into  the  Government’s  PNPM  Mandiri  and  the  project 
implementation arrangements are aligned with the PNPM Mandiri mechanisms. 
 
The  Project  is  in  line  with  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  Indonesia  for  the  period  2006–2009,  which 
includes  investments  in  rural  infrastructure  as  strategic  key  area  of  engagement  to  address  poverty  and  regional 
disparities, and achieve the MDGs.

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Indonesia’s infrastructure, particularly in rural areas, is deteriorating. Electrification rates are the lowest in the region, 
road  network  congestion  is  increasing,  and  conditions  of  rural  roads  are  poor.  A  lack  of  access  to  infrastructure 
results in location poverty, in which people living in isolated areas with difficult geography and poor market linkages 
lack both economic opportunities and adequate levels of service delivery. More than 15% of all Indonesian villages 
are  inaccessible,  even  by  4-wheel-drive  vehicles,  at  certain  times  of  the  year.  Investments  in  transportation 
infrastructure, agricultural infrastructure (irrigation), and education and health facilities can significantly improve living 
conditions in remote areas, create the basis for economic growth, and make a major difference in the welfare of the 
local population. Poor quality roads or even no roads mean that government services seldom enter the region. Once 
isolated regions can be reached, services will follow. The positive effect of infrastructure on rural welfare has been 
empirically  demonstrated.  Surveys  have  revealed  that  the  presence  of  good  roads  is  strongly  and  significantly 
correlated with a community’s level of mean income.  
 
Approximately  60%  of  the  population  lives  in  rural  areas  where  agriculture  is  the  main  source  of  livelihood.  One 
reason for low incomes in the agriculture sector is that ‘farm gate prices’ are very low as compared to the urban price 
for  the  same  good  of  the  same  quality.    Farm  gate  prices  are  low  as  a  result  of  high  real  transport  costs  for  rural 
marketable  surpluses  over  poor  quality  roads.  Transport  costs  are  even  higher  for  non-motor-vehicle  transport 
methods in areas where roads are absent.  In a rapid assessment of causes of poverty in five of Indonesia’s districts, 
villagers in isolated areas identified high transport costs to be a major cause of poverty. New roads in previously un-
served agricultural areas can significantly lower transaction costs and hence raise farm gate prices, which will mean 
higher incomes for people in the agriculture sector, the poorest group of the population. Improvement of rural roads 
will  help  agriculture  extension  workers  reach  rural  farmers  to  provide  technical  advice  and  know-how  to  increase 
productivity. 
 
To further enhance the quality of life in poor rural communities, access to social services is crucial and infrastructure 
investments  can  accelerate  social  development.  Lack  of  access  to  quality  education  significantly  decreases 
productivity,  employment  opportunities,  and  personal  income.  With  improved  roads  and  better  education  facilities, 
teachers  might  be  more  willing  to  staff  rural  schools  and  the  teaching  and  learning  environment  would  improve, 
thereby  increasing  human  capital.  Health  and  hygiene  problems  are  still  major  causes  of  poverty  in  Indonesia. 
Through a serious illness or an accident, a family can easily lose any accumulated assets. Road improvements and 
investments  to  improve  drinking  water  quality  and  rehabilitate  basic  health  facilities  will  contribute  to  increased 
access  to  and  quality  of  health  services  in  rural  communities.  The  list  of  potential  social  benefits  through 
infrastructure investments can be further enlarged.

C.   Gender and Development 

Key  Issues.  The  country  gender  assessment  identified  four  key  themes  through  a  consultative  process:  (i)  the 
impact  of  decentralization  on  gender,  (ii)  women’s  inadequate  representation  in  political  decision-making,  (iii) 
violence  against  women,  and  (iv)  women  and  international  migration.  It  noted  that  while  Indonesia  has  made 
progress  over  the  years,  gender  inequalities  persist.  Gender-disaggregated  data  is  lacking.  Indonesia  was  ranked 
107th  globally  in  both  gender  and  human  development  indexes  in  2008.  Women’s  longer  life  expectancy  is  more 
than  offset  by  a  much  lower  literacy  rate  and  a  small  share  of  earned  income.  In  2007,  women’s  labor  force 
participation was only 40%, compared with 80% for men. The shift to regional autonomy has already shown potential 
for increased participation of women in local governance, but decentralization has sometimes been accompanied by 
a revival of conservative religious interpretations of gender roles. 
 
Key  Actions. Drawing a comprehensive conclusion on issues related to gender and income poverty in Indonesia is 
difficult  as  consistent  disaggregated  data  by  sex  is  not  available  throughout  the  country.  However,  the  community 
participation approach applied by the Project will ensure that perspectives of both men and women are represented 
in  planning,  designing,  and  implementing  the  village  infrastructure  investments.  The  village  representative 
committees  will  include  at  least  one  woman,  and  committee  membership  will  be  at  least  20%  women.  Experience 
from  the  PNPM  Mandiri  reveal  that  the  number  of  women  on  the  committees  varies  from  few  women  to  entirely 
women, depending on the circumstances of individual villages. Although it is difficult to measure participation of men 
and  women  in  construction,  some  tasks  tend  to  be  done  more  by  women,  such  as  finishing  work  on  masonry  and 
concrete, ground clearing preparations, spreading gravel, leveling and filling work, and other tasks requiring attention 
to detail and manual dexterity. The types of expected infrastructure works present opportunities to provide temporary 
casual labor to both men and women. Measures included in project design to promote gender equality and women’s 
empowerment include access to and use of relevant services, resources, assets, and opportunities; and participation

A. 

Overview 

BENEFITS ANALYSIS 
 

The Project will support rural infrastructure rehabilitation and expansion, providing about 
1. 
1,650  villages  with  financial  resources  and  technical  backstopping  for  small  interventions, 
including  village  roads,  bridges  and  culverts,  village  irrigation  schemes,  water  supply  and 
sanitation.  Under  the  Project,  village  investments  will  follow  a  community-driven  development 
approach, designs and costs of selected interventions will be determined during implementation. 
Quantifiable  benefits  will  arise  from  village  rural  investments  as  increased  rural  incomes  and 
welfare,  but,  because  beneficiaries  determine  investments,  the  Project’s  actual  inputs  and 
outputs cannot be predicted up front. The Project, therefore, does not lend itself to a traditional 
economic analysis. 
 
B. 

Likely Benefits and Impacts of Rural Infrastructure 

Rural  Infrastructure  Benefits. The more common benefits expected to accrue include 
2. 
(i)  time  savings  in  collecting  water  and  cost  savings  in  obtaining  water;  (ii)  emergence  of  new 
businesses  due  to  access  to  a  water  supply;  (iii)  time  and  cost  savings  due  to  faster 
transportation,  including  more  efficient  transportation  of  goods  to  market;  (iv)  increase  in  the 
value of land adjacent to a new road; (v) new employment in the transport sector; (vi) increase 
in the value of agricultural land serviced by new irrigation works; (vii) increase in incomes due to 
better  harvests  resulting  from  a  reliable  water  supply;  (viii)  savings  from  potential  damage  to 
buildings  and  crops  due  to  reduced  flooding  and  improved  irrigation,  and  (ix)  creation  of  new 
businesses (roads). 
 
3. 
Employment  Generation.  The  Government  of  Indonesia’s  (Government)  ongoing 
National Program for Community Empowerment (PNPM Mandiri) estimates that 30% to 50% of 
the  total  civil  works  inputs  will  consist  of  labor.  The  successful  implementation  of  the  RISP 
confirms  these  estimates.  Even  if  using  a  conservative  estimate  of  30%  of  village  grant 
utilization, the Project is expected to generate an average of 100 person-months of employment 
per village, or about a total 160,000 person-months.  
 
4. 
Poverty  Reduction  Impact.  By  2010,  when  PNPM  Mandiri  will  cover  all  existing 
kecamatan  (subdistricts)  in  the  country,  it  is  expected  to  benefit  30  million  workers  and  their 
families, increasing their income by an estimated 12% for 60 days of work, on average.  About 
10 million families are expected to be pulled out of poverty. The civil works will be undertaken by 
the  communities  when  they  have  time  free  from  their  usual  income-generating  activities. 
Additional income will benefit workers primarily when they need it the most—when there are few 
other jobs, mainly because it is the off-season in agriculture. The benefits will be more important 
than an estimated 12% increase in annual income would suggest. Thus, the PNPM Mandiri will 
improve the social safety net for the rural poor.  
 
5. 
Improvement  of  roads,  irrigation  and  drainage  works,  and  water  supply  and  sanitation 
works  will  permanently  increase  employment  and  income.  Evidence  from  studies  has  shown 
that rural transport improvements (i) contribute to decreasing the costs to the poor for personal 
travel  and  transporting  goods;  (ii)  increase  the  range  of  opportunities  for  wage  employment, 
thereby raising the price of labor in rural areas; and (iii) empower the poor by increasing their

processes and management structures.1 
 
6. 
Other  Benefits. In addition to the direct and indirect yields from the rural infrastructure 
investments,  the  Project  will  improve  the  internal  governance  of  project  communities  by 
promoting  broad-based  participation,  constituent  accountability,  and  strengthened  governance 
institutions  such  as  the  village  councils,  community  user  groups;  and  increasing  access  to 
countervailing  institutions.  The  Project  will  also  contribute  to  improvement  of  the  local 
governments planning processes through introduction of the bottom-up planning and budgeting 
approach.  These,  however,  are  Project  activities  for  which  input  costs  are  identifiable,  but 
benefits and outputs cannot be predicted with accuracy.

Evidence from the Previous Projects 

7. 
The  existence  and  significance  of  the  economic  benefits  of  rural  infrastructure 
investments that are expected to derive from the Project, overall and by type of intervention, are 
confirmed  by  extensive  experience  in  Indonesia.  In  particular,  since  the  design  of  the  PNPM 
Mandiri  is  based  on  the  lessons  from  implementation  of  the  World  Bank-financed  Kecamatan 
Development  Programs 
(KDPs)  and  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-financed  Rural 
Infrastructure Support Project (RISP), the benefits generated under these projects will reflect the 
benefits  expected  to  be  generated  under  the  Project.  The  evidence  from  implementation  of 
these  two  successful  programs  verified  very  significant  benefits  from  similar  community-based 
interventions.  
 

1. 

Rural Infrastructure Support Project (RISP) 

8. 
The 2007 evaluation of the RISP did not undertake a quantitative analysis of the impact 
of  that  project.  However,  the  qualitative  evaluation  confirmed  that  rural  infrastructure 
investments had a positive impact on poverty reduction, stimulated village economic activities, 
and  represented  an  important  source  of  primary  and  secondary  employment  that  generated 
additional  disposable  income  for  the  villagers.  The  evaluation  shows  that  project  performance 
was  rated  as  fully  satisfactory  in  94%  of  the  project  villages  and  partly  satisfactory  in  the 
remaining 6%. No village rated project performance as unsatisfactory.  
 
9. 
Overall,  the  RISP  generated  more  than  160,000  person-days  of  employment.  The 
evaluation  study  noted  a  high  level  of  satisfaction  among  the  communities  receiving  rural 
infrastructure interventions, increased sense of community ownership, and enthusiastic support 
from the communities. 
 
 
 
10. 
The  PNPM  Mandiri  design  is  largely  based  on  the  design  of  the  World  Bank’s  KDPs.

transferred  directly  to  the  community  organizations’  bank  accounts.  These  funds  cover 
construction  costs  related  to  materials,  equipment,  and  labor.  The  average  community  grants 
under the first two phases of KDP were about $25,000 per village, which is similar to the village
